item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Defining hardware requirements for Ethereum entities is important because it parametrizes what we mean by decentralization, enables informed decision making about protocol upgrades and allows for meaningful benchmark comparisons.
We have been gathering feedback on the current recommendations for validators:
- $1,000 total spend - 8 cores/16 threads CPU - 4TB SSD - 32GB RAM minimum
Less powerful machines work today, but these specs would guide protocol changes related to validators.
item.dc:creator: @kevaundray

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Don't sleep on ERC-7846: the Wallet Connection API.
Currently (Image 1), connecting a Wallet with SIWE and/or other connection actions requires 2+ user interactions.
We can make it one user interaction with `wallet_connect` by leveraging ERC-5792 capabilities (Image 2).

item.title: R to @gakonst: Truthfully I don't view EVMMAX/SIMD as a good use of time. The EVM on L1 is not gonna be doing much compute, it's coordinating asset transfers with some light math. We don't need to add a general purpose abstraction for adding new crypto. On L2s we'll have JIT/AOT or RISC-V runtimes.

item.title: R to @gakonst: We can do smarter pricing of SLOAD/SSTORE by having block-level context information. SSTORE'ing to the same slot many times in a block shouldn't cost like a cold SSTORE. SLOAD'ing the same slot across transactions should assume the read was in memory the 2nd time. Easy wins.
